unnormalised: Loans in India, ah, the ultimate relationship status: it's complicated. Everyone wants that sweet loan nectar, but nobody wants to pay it back. Let’s be real, the repayment journey is longer than a Bollywood movie, and sometimes just as dramatic. Banks dangling attractive interest rates like '8.5% p.a.' makes you think you’re getting a great deal. Until you realize that 'p.a.' means *per annum*, and suddenly your monthly EMI looks like your electricity bill during peak summer!
normalised: Loans in India, ah, the ultimate relationship status: it is complicated. Everyone wants that sweet loan nectar, but nobody wants to pay it back. Let us be real, the repayment journey is longer than a Bollywood movie, and sometimes just as dramatic. Banks dangling attractive interest rates like eight point five percent per annum makes you think you are getting a great deal. Until you realize that P-A means per annum, and suddenly your monthly E-M-I looks like your electricity bill during peak summer!

unnormalised: First, there's the dream. You picture yourself chilling in Goa, all thanks to that sweet Rs. 50,00,000 loan you took for your "start-up." Then reality hits harder than a Mumbai monsoon. The lender calls, "Sir, your EMI of Rs. 45,000 is due." You contemplate faking amnesia, or maybe a sudden trip to the Himalayas.
normalised: First, there is the dream. You picture yourself chilling in Goa, all thanks to that sweet rupee fifty lakh loan you took for your "start-up." Then reality hits harder than a Mumbai monsoon. The lender calls, "Sir, your E-M-I of rupee forty five thousand is due." You contemplate faking amnesia, or maybe a sudden trip to the Himalayas.

unnormalised: Then there's the paperwork. Mountains of forms, more confusing than a physics textbook. You need your PAN card, Aadhaar, salary slips, property documents – basically your entire life story on A4 paper. The bank manager, with his laser-like focus on finding any excuse to reject your application, examines every comma and full stop as if it's a national secret. You swear you saw him use a magnifying glass on your signature!

The bank manager, with his laser-like focus on finding any excuse to reject your application, examines every comma and full stop as if it is a national secret. You swear you saw him use a magnifying glass on your signature!

unnormalised: And the interest rates? A moving target, my friend. One day it’s ‘fixed’ at 8.75%, the next it’s dancing around with the market like a Bollywood item number. Suddenly, your carefully calculated budget goes for a toss, and you find yourself eating Maggi for the rest of the month. Rs. 250 becomes a luxury purchase!
normalised: And the interest rates? A moving target, my friend. One day it is ‘fixed’ at eight point seven five percent, the next it is dancing around with the market like a Bollywood item number. Suddenly, your carefully calculated budget goes for a toss, and you find yourself eating Maggi for the rest of the month. Rupee two hundred and fifty becomes a luxury purchase!

unnormalised: The collateral. Oh, the collateral. Banks want your life savings, your grandmother's gold, and possibly your firstborn child as security. They look at your property documents like they're inspecting a diamond mine. "Is the property worth the Rs. 1 Cr we're lending?" they ask, with a skeptical glare. You feel like you're auditioning for Shark Tank India, but instead of funding, you're just begging for a loan.

They look at your property documents like they are inspecting a diamond mine. "Is the property worth the rupee one crore we are lending?" they ask, with a skeptical glare. You feel like you are auditioning for Shark Tank India, but instead of funding, you are just begging for a loan.

unnormalised: But hey, at least you're not alone. Millions of Indians are navigating this loan-repayment rollercoaster together. We're all in the same auto-rickshaw, bumping along a pothole-filled road, praying we reach our destination (financial freedom) before the vehicle falls apart. And who knows, maybe one day we'll all be chilling in Goa... without the bank breathing down our necks. Fingers crossed!
